WHOOSH! That car's going a little too FAST!
The two couples wander around this historic site.
The girls have led them to a beautiful spot.

we see the progress of their picnic. We don't hear them, there is a growing intimacy about their interaction. Even Maya and Miles seem to be overcoming residual awkwardness from the other night. Jack and Stephanie lean on each oth as they eat and sip wine. Finally, the two couples are SILHOUETTED against the SUNS
The parking lot is crowded. The foursome join others head toward the main building.
A LECTURE by British wine sage LESLIE BROUGH is in progre He holds aloft a RIEDEL BURGUNDY GLASS containing one of few but growing number of local reds worthy of his attent
As our foursome listen attentively, Jack leans over to Mi
You ever actually read any of this  guy's books?

He wrote a great one on Burgundy,  and I used to get his newsletter,  but then there were doubts about  whether he does all his own tasting.  Plus a couple of times he declared  certain years vintages of the century,  and they turned out to be turkeys.  Fucker never retracted.
Huh.
Stephanie leans forward and signals to Maya with a YAWN o GAGGING FINGER IN MOUTH that they hightail it. Although M protests at first, they stand and leave.

head_text.subj: AT THE BACK OF THE ROOM --

text: Stephanie finds a DOOR which she tests to see whether it open. It is! She leads her pals furtively inside --

This is an enormous, dimly-lit chamber filled with stainl steel FERMENTATION TANKS and stacks of OAK BARRELS. As the two couples walk in the near-darkness, they are  entranced. Maya takes Miles's hand and leads him away.

In the background, Stephanie and Jack lean against a tank kissing. CAMERA DOLLIES to reveal Miles and Maya among the barrels the foreground. They are shy with each other, on the verg of kissing but holding back. THE MUSIC CONTINUES...
THREE BOTTLES OF WINE sit empty on the coffee table.

The four friends sit on the floor around the coffee table They drink wine and pass a JOINT. Suddenly they explode i LAUGHTER. A sleepy Siena appears at the hallway door rubbing her ey Stephanie gets up, but Jack stops her, gathers Siena in h arms, and takes her back to bed.
The Saab pulls away from the house.
Miles sits in his own passenger seat as Maya tries her ha at the Saab.
Maya leads Miles up her back stairway. They're both a lit woozy from the hours of drinking.

Maya searches through her purse for her keys while Miles  hovers directly behind her, staring at her ear. Her ear? Just as Maya puts the key in the lock, he impulsively lea forward to kiss the nape of her neck. Maya's reaction is  immediate -- she turns to embrace Miles, giving him a lon KISS. Then she opens the door, pulls him inside and close the door in our face. The camera PANS to the nearby ROOFTOPS.

head_text.transition: MUSIC ENDS AND SLOW DISSOLVE TO:

head_text.subj: THE SAME VIEW BY DAY, SUPERIMPOSED WITH --

text: The CAMERA PANS back to Maya's door, tilting down to find blue-wrapped NEW YORK TIMES. The door opens, and Maya's h picks up the newspaper. The CAMERA FOLLOWS Maya inside to
It is a small, clean apartment furnished with simple tast Maya is dressed in a ROBE and holds a COFFEE MUG. She dro the paper on the dining table and continues into --
where Miles lies on his stomach DEAD TO THE WORLD. His st face is squished against the mattress and he SNORES light Maya looks at him for a moment before shaking his foot.
This is a weekly event in a big PARKING LOT -- organic  produce, candles and incense, honey and cider. Maya and Miles are shopping. Miles carries the bags.
Across from each other at a PICNIC TABLE, and surrounded the remnants of BREAKFAST, Miles and Maya read the NEWSPA Miles is doing the CROSSWORD PUZZLE.
You guys should stop by the restaurant  for lunch today.
Great. What's the latest we can get  there?
About two-thirty.
Okay.

(noticing) Did you hear about this Bordeaux  tasting dinner down in Santa Barbara  Saturday night? It's a little pricey,  but if you wanted to go, I'd be into  it. Why don't you stay through the  weekend?
Miles has just figured out a difficult clue. As he writes down --
No, we've got to get back Friday for  the rehearsal dinner.
What rehearsal dinner?
Miles stops writing.
Who's getting married?
Maya leads the way toward the Saab.
Were you ever going to say anything?
Of course I was. I mean, just now I  could have made up some story, but I  didn't. I told you the truth.
Maya turns to confront Miles with a look of "Give me a br Miles reaches out to touch her.
Maya.
(jerking away) Don't touch me. Just take me home.
Miles drives, glancing occasionally at Maya, who stares  straight ahead.
I've told him. I've told him over  and over, but he's out of control.
Do you know what he's been saying to  her?
He's an actor, so it can't be good.

Oh, just that he loves her. That  she's the only woman who has ever  really rocked his world. How he adores  Siena. How he wants to move up here  and get a place with the two of them  and commute when he has to.
I'm sure he believed every word.
A stony silence.
Please believe me. I was even on the  verge of telling you last night,  but...
But you wanted to fuck me first.
Oh, Maya. No.
Yeah.
Miles brings the car to a stop. Maya opens the door and b to get out.
You know, I just spent three years  trying to extricate myself from a  relationship that turned out to be  full of deception. And I've been  doing just fine.

And I haven't been with anyone since  my divorce. This has been a big deal  for me, Maya -- hanging out with  you, and last night. I really like  you, Maya. And I'm not Jack. I'm  just his... his freshman roommate  from San Diego State.
Maya wants to let Miles's words reach her, but she can't  just yet.
Could I have my paper, please?
Unsure what she wants at first, Miles reaches into the ba seat for the New York Times. He hands it to her and watch until she goes inside.
Miles pulls up and parks.
As Miles enters, a shirtless Jack drops the Barely Legal is immediately upon him, grabbing him in a big BEARHUG. T TV is on, perhaps showing an E! True Hollywood Story.
Yo! Yo! Here's my boy! Here's my  boy! Who's your daddy, boy? Who is  yo' daddy?
Put me down, Jack.
Jack continues his paean to Miles's triumphant night.
I said put me down. Jack!
Still gripping Miles in a bearhug, Jack flings the both o them onto the bed. Now on top of Miles, Jack KISSES both  cheeks.
I'm so proud of you! Let me love  you!
Now they get up off the bed.
So tell me everything. Details. I  like details.
No.
What?
It's private.
You're kidding, right? Tell me what  happened, you fucker, or I'll tie  your dick in a knot.
Let's leave it alone.
Jack looks at Miles, his face frozen with incomprehension
You didn't get any, did you? (off Miles's silence) You're a homo.

Just stop, okay? Make something up,  and that's what happened. Whatever  you want. Write my confession, and  I'll sign it. Just stop pushing me  all the time! I can't take it! You're  an infant! This is all a big party  for you, but not for me! This is  serious. And you -- Just... leave me  alone, okay? You're fucking me up.
Wow. Okay. Calm down. Sorry.
Miles begins to calm down. Jack grows concerned and  sensitively puts one arm around his friend.
Did you have trouble performing?  Yeah, that's...
Shut up! Shut up, Jack!
The phone RINGS and both men look at it, silenced by the  ominous sound.
Don't answer it.
But Jack is drawn to it as though enticed by a strange ga of Russian roulette.
I'm telling you, don't.
Jack picks up the receiver and puts it to his ear.
Hello? Oh, hey, honey. How you doing?  Uh-huh. Uh-huh. (mouthing) Christine.
Miles lies on his bed and clamps both hands over his ears His face is dark with resentment.

Listen, honey. Let me call you back.  Miles and I are in the middle of  something. No, it's nothing serious --  Miles is just having one of his freak- outs. Yeah. Love you too. I'll call  you right back.
Jack hangs up.
This whole week has gone sour. It  isn't turning out like it was supposed  to. (deadly serious) I want to go home.
Who's being selfish now? I'm the one  getting married. I thought this week  was supposed to be about me.
We gotta slow down. (closing his eyes) I'm so tired. Let's just get out of  here.
I know what you need.
Jack watches Miles be fitted for SNEAKERS. A SALES ASSOCI ties Miles's laces.
There you go.
Miles gets up and walks in a circle.
Do you like them?
Yeah, they're great. Sporty. They're  really sporty.
Are they too sporty?
The boys exit Sears, Miles wearing his new shoes and carr a PLASTIC BAG with a string handle.
Feel better?
Miles shrugs.
(noticing something) Oh here, wait a second. I want to  run in here real quick.
He heads toward a TOYS STORE.
(over his shoulder) I want to get something for Siena.
Mildly concerned, Miles watches Jack go into the store.
Miles is slumped in the passenger seat as Jack drives. Th pass a BIG COMMERCIAL WINERY. Jack slows down, preparing turn in.
How about this one? We didn't hit  this one.
Yeah, it's Frass Canyon. It's a joke.
You ever actually been in there,  Miles?
I don't have to.
(turning the wheel) I say we check it out. You never  know.
The Saab finds a place in the large parking lot. A TOUR B whose flank reads "Solvang Wine Tours," is in the process letting out WINE TOURISTS, many of them elderly.

The room boasts not only a large TASTING BAR but also dis after display of t-shirts, golf shirts, olive oils, choco sauces and other gourmet tourist items emblazoned with th winery's logo. In the corner an ACOUSTIC GUITARIST with a small amp play soothing Windham Hill-ish music. The tasting bar is packed three-deep with TASTERS attende to by HARRIED POURERS. Finally the POURER gets to their glasses. Miles chews a s and swallows, then downs the rest in a single gulp.

Tastes like the back of a fucking LA  schoolbus. Probably didn't de-stem,  hoping for some semblance of  concentration, crushed it up with  leaves and mice, wound up with this  rancid tar and turpentine mouthwash  bullshit. Fucking Raid.
I don't know. Tastes okay to me. (looking at the tasting  sheet) Hey, they got a reserve pinot.
Let me use your phone.
(handing it over) What's up?
I can't take it anymore. I've got to  call Evelyn.
Walking across the lawn outside, Miles holds the cellphon to his ear.
Evelyn Berman-Silverman's office.
Hi, it's Miles.
Oh, hi, Miles. Let me see if I can  get her. (a moment later) You're in luck. I'll put you through.
Miles.
Hey, Evelyn, it's your favorite  client.
How's the trip?
Good, good. Drinking some good wines  and kicking back, you know. So what's  happening? Still no word?
Actually there is word. I spoke to  Keith Kurtzman this morning.
And?
And... they're passing. Conundrum's  passing. He said they really liked  it. They really wanted to do it, but  they just couldn't figure out how to  market it. He said it was a tough  call.
Huh.

I'm sorry, Miles. (off his silence) So I don't know where that leaves  us. I'm not sure how much more mileage  I can get out of continuing to submit  it. I think it's one of those  unfortunate cases in the business  right now -- a fabulous book with no  home. The whole industry's gotten  gutless. It's not about the quality  of the books. It's about the  marketing.
Miles is at a loss for words. A distant RUMBLE begins to  sound, the familiar harbinger of an anxiety attack.
Once again we see the narrow ROPE BRIDGE extending  vertiginously across a great CHASM.
Are you there? Miles?
Yeah, I'm here.
I'm sorry, Miles. We did all we could.  You've been a real trooper. (loudly, to her  assistant) Tell him I'll call back.
So I guess that's it.
You're a wonderful writer, Miles.  Don't be discouraged.
Miles STAGGERS toward the tasting room, unpocketing his X and downing a couple, as Evelyn's cliches of consolation  continue in his head.
Just hang in there, and who knows?  After you get something else  published, we can revisit this one.  And next time we can try a different  title.
Once back at the tent, he leans against it in a vain atte to steady himself. The RUMBLE grows deafening.

Now inside, Miles grabs the first DIRTY WINE GLASS he fin and shakes it out as he approaches the closest tasting  station. He pushes his way to front. The pourer offers the usual one-ounce dollop. Miles jacks back, immediately extending his glass for more.
Hit me again.
The same small amount is poured and downed. Once again Mi holds out his glass.
Pour me a full glass. I'll pay for  it.
This is a tasting, sir. Not a bar.
Miles slams a TWENTY-DOLLAR BILL on the table.
Just give me a full goddamn pour.

The pourer turns away to serve another party. Miles looks around indignantly, as though everyone should be sympathe to this injustice. Now Miles boldly reaches over and pours himself a glass r up to the brim and beyond.
Sir, what are you doing?
I told you I need a drink.
Then buy a bottle and go outside.
The pourer grabs Miles by the wrist before he can drink.
Put the glass down.
In the ensuing struggle, the wine spills, and everyone ne steps back.
You're going to have to leave, sir.

The pourer signals to a SECURITY GUY at the door. Across room Jack notices the disturbance and heads over. Miles hoists up the SPIT BUCKET, holds it aloft and start to GUZZLE it. Wine cascades down the sides of his face, o his shirt and even onto his shiny new shoes. The Security Guy yanks the bucket away from Miles, and dr him toward the EXIT. Jack catches up.
(to the horrified  onlookers) It's all right. His mother just died.
Two PELICANS soar low over the water. One of the DIVES,  crashing into the water and disappearing from view. Jack and Miles sit on the hood of the Saab, gazing at the ocean, sharing a bottle of wine.
Just write another one. You have  lots of ideas, right?

No, I'm finished. I'm not a writer.  I'm a middle-school English teacher.  I'm going to spend the rest of my  life grading essays and reading the  works of others. It's okay. I like  books. The world doesn't give a shit  what I have to say. I'm unnecessary. (a dark laugh) I'm so insignificant, I can't even  kill myself.
What's that supposed to mean?
You know -- Hemingway, Sexton, Woolf,  Plath, Delmore Schwartz. You can't  kill yourself before you've even  been published.
What about that guy who wrote  Confederacy of Dunces? He committed  suicide before he got published, and  look how famous he is.
Thanks.
Don't give up. You're going to make  it.

Half my life is over, and I have  nothing to show for it. I'm a  thumbprint on the window of a  skyscraper. I'm a smudge of excrement  on a tissue surging out to sea with  a million tons of raw sewage.
See? Right there. Just what you just  said. That's beautiful. A thumbprint  on a skyscraper. I couldn't write  that.
Neither could I. I think it's  Bukowski.
Unable to respond, Jack looks up and down the beach.
ZOOM! There goes the Saab. The CAMERA lingers behind and PANS to reveal THE DEAD DOG now covered with FLIES AND MAGGOTS.
Jack and Miles pull into the parking lot.
(lighting up) Oh, look. There's Steph!
He smiles broadly and honks his horn. Miles turns to see
seated halfway up on the motel stairs, her HELMET in her  lap, watching patiently as --
pulls to a stop in a parking space. Miles masks his concern as he gets out of the car and rea in the backseat for his Sears bag.
(calling out) Hey, baby.
Stephanie stands up and slowly descends the steps, as Jac reaches into the trunk and pulls out a BIG CUDDLY LION DO
Look what I got for our favorite  girl.
Stephanie walks toward Jack as he waddles toward her hugg the lion. When they get close, Stephanie's face transform with rage.
YOU MOTHERFUCKER!

She swings her helmet and HITS JACK FULL IN THE FACE. Jack falls, blood spraying out of his nose. Stephanie sta over him and continues to BEAT HIM with her helmet as he  rolls back and forth, protecting his head with the stuffe lion. Miles ineffectually attempts to stop her, dancing just ou of range.
Stephanie! Stop!
You fucking bastard! Lying piece of  shit! You're getting married on  Saturday? What was all that shit you  said to me?
I can explain.
You said you loved me! You fuck! I  hope you die!
With that she backs away. Glancing at her bloodied helmet she tosses it onto the pavement before getting on her bik
Fuckface! (to Miles) You too!
As she speeds away, Miles is left to comfort his wounded  friend. The lion lies nearby, staring blankly at the sky.
Seated in the passenger seat and in great agony, Jack pre a BLOOD-SOAKED TOWEL against his face.
Aren't you glad you didn't move up  here and marry her?
Don't need a lecture. You fucking  told Maya, didn't you?
No, I did not. Must have been Gary  at the Hitching Post. I think we  mentioned it to him the first night.
You told him. I'm fucking hurting  here.
Keep it elevated.
CLOSE ON A COSMOPOLITAN open to an article titled "24 Way To Please Your Man."
Miles reads, while nearby a YOUNG BOY dry-heaves into a  garbage can held by his FATHER. An OLD WOMAN parked in a  wheelchair faces the wall.
Miles is at a PAYPHONE. As he speaks he tries to peel off the metal LONG DISTANCE STICKER.
Hi. It's Maya. Please leave a message.

It's Miles. Listen, I don't know if  you even care, but I had to call and  tell you again how much I enjoyed  our time together and how sorry I am  things turned out the way they did.  I think you're great, Maya -- always  have. From the first time you waited  on me. (bracing himself) And while I'm at it, I guess you  should know that my book is not  getting published. I thought this  one had a chance, but I was wrong.  Again. Don't bother reading it --  you've got better things to do. So  you see I'm not much of a writer.  I'm not anything really. The only  real talent I seem to have is for  disappointing people and now you  know that firsthand. We're leaving  in the morning, and I want you to  know that I take with me wonderful  memories of you. I'm sorry. I'm really  sorry.
What else to say? He hangs up. He returns to his seat. A moment later he extends his leg to look at his new SHOES now STAINED WITH WINE.
Jack emerges unsteadily from the bowels of the emergency  room, his face purple and swollen beneath the HUGE WHITE  BANDAGE that holds the NOSEGUARD in place. Miles walks wi him toward the exit.
Well?
I'm going to need an operation. Maybe  a couple of them. They have to wait  for it it to heal first. Then they  break it again.
Good thing you have a voice-over  career.
Gonna fuck that up too. I should sue  her ass. Only reason I won't is to  protect Christine.
That's thoughtful.
(disgusted) Yeah.
They walk by us and out the door.

Jack sits in the Saab's passenger side with the seat almo fully reclined. When his agony allows him to open his eye he glares at the DANISH THEMED STORES lining the street. ABELSKIVER MAKER plies his lofty trade in a nearby window He hears a strange CLOMPING NOISE and turns his head to s a MAN IN WOODEN CLOGS walking noisily down the street, dr in a TRADITIONAL DANISH COSTUME and carrying a TUBA. Jack takes a slug of wine. Just then Miles gets back in the car.
I hate this place.
Miles tears open a paper bag and removes a bottle of pill A closer angle reveals them as VICODIN.
Take a couple of these, and you'll  learn to love it.
Miles opens the bottle and hands Jack two PILLS.
Two for you. And two for me.
Jack washes down the pills and passes the bottle to Miles who follows suit.
Jack and Miles sit across from each other. For the first  time we see LARGE PURPLE BRUISES on Jack's arms and chest
So how did Stephanie know it was  Saturday? We didn't get into that  with Gary.
Huh. Let me think.
You sure you didn't say anything to  Maya?

Sure I'm sure. And just what are you  implying? I'm really pissed off at  you about all this, if you want to  know the truth. What's Maya going to  think of me now just for associating  with you? You're the one who's  sabotaging me, not the other way  around, pal. Not by a longshot.
Jack takes a long lie-detecting look at Miles.
I don't know. Just seems fishy.
The boys lie on their respective beds staring at the TV.  Jack gets up and lumbers slowly to the dresser MIRROR lik large dog who has just been neutered.
What's it look like to you?
Looks like you were in a bad car  accident.
Jack turns to Miles, nodding and thinking. Then he looks  back in the mirror.
I'm hungry.
Establishing. Thursday night is Cajun Wings Night.
Miles and Jack are finishing their SALADS in the rustic-  themed restaurant festooned with animal trophies.
You know what I'm thinking?
What's that?
I'm thinking it's time to settle  down. One woman. One house. You know.  It's time.
Uh-huh.
Jack nods his head with no self-awareness or acknowledgme of the irony.
mounded high with ribs, slaw, beans and butter-whipped ma potatoes.
Mm. Mm.
Their cheery, saftig blonde WAITRESS removes several FOIL PACKETS from her apron and places them on the table.
And here're your Handi-wipes.
Oh, so that's what those are? For a  second there I thought you guys were  promoting safe sex.
The waitress OVER-LAUGHS and swipes a hand at her naughty customer.
I'll be right back with more corn  bread.
Jack watches her go and leans in close to Miles.
I bet you that chick is two tons of  fun. You know, the grateful type.
I don't know. I wouldn't know.

Now she comes back toward the table carrying a BIG BASKET Beneath the hideous uniform, her nylons SH-SH-SH as she w When she arrives, she replenishes their corn bread basket using big TONGS. Jack watches attentively.
Nice technique there... (checking her name  tag) ...Cammi.
It's all in the wrist. (a moment later) You know, you look really familiar.  You from around here? Where'd you go  to high school?
No, we're from San Diego. Why?
I don't know. You just seem really  familiar to me. Never mind. Enjoy  your meals.
Hang on. Did you ever know a Derek  Sommersby?
Doctor Derek Sommersby? You mean  from "One Life to Live"?
Miles looks away and sighs.
You have to imagine him with a bandage  and shorter hair.
As Cammi stares at Jack, her face transforms in astonishm
No. Way. No way!
Jack smiles and nods.
Oh, my God!
Could you tell me where the bathroom  is?
(her eyes barely  leaving Jack) Uh, sure, it's right over there,  right past the buffalo.

Miles gets up and heads toward the bathroom as Jack's  flirtation with Cammi continues. The camera PANS with Miles as he walks by us and goes thr the bathroom door, which closes behind him, filling the f with the word "MEN."
A TOOTHPICK DISPENSER as a finger tips it forward to disp one.
Miles stands by the cash register and PICKS HIS TEETH as watches Jack finish speaking with Cammi and head his way.
She gets off in an hour, so I think  I'm just going to have a drink and  then... make sure she gets home safe.
You're joking, right? (seeing that he isn't) What are you doing? Un-fucking- believeable. Can we just go back to  the hotel and hang out and get up  early and play nine holes before we  head home?
Jack rests one hand on Miles's shoulder and drops his hea thinking how best to put it.

Look, Miles. I know you're my friend  and you care about me. And I know  you disapprove. I respect that. But  there are some things I have to do  that you don't understand. You  understand wine and literature and  movies, but you don't understand my  plight. And that's okay.
as the disappointment in his friend deepens by the moment
Now comes the sound of hysterical KNOCKING.
Despite the knocking, Miles remains motionless in bed, hi expression serene. Finally he awakens and drags himself toward the door, ope it to find --
silhouetted against the first rosy fingers of dawn. He is barefoot. In fact he is clad only in his UNDERWEAR. Huggi himself, he PANTS and SHIVERS.
Jesus fucking Christ, it's freezing.
He limps past Miles, yanks off the bed covers and wraps t around himself.
Vicodin. Where's the Vicodin? My  nose.
Miles hands him the bottle, and Jack frantically pops a c of pills, chewing them like candy. He sits down and bends over at the waist as though preparing for an airplane cra
Fucking chick's married.
What?
Her husband works a night shift or  something, and he comes home, and  I'm on the floor with my cock in his  wife's ass.
Jesus, Jack. Jesus. And you walked  all the way back from Solvang?
Ran. Twisted my ankle too.
That's five clicks, Jackson.
Fucking-a it's five clicks! At one  point I had to cut through an ostrich  farm. Fuckers are mean.
Miles has now awakened to take in the absurdity of the wh scene, and he LAUGHS HARD. The blanketed bulge just sits  there. Finally it looks up and shows its pitiful visage.
We gotta go back.
What?
I left my wallet. My credit cards,  cash, fucking ID, everything. We  gotta go back.
Big deal. We'll call right now and  cancel your cards.
You don't understand. The wedding  bands. The wedding bands are in my  wallet.
Okay, so they were in your wallet,  and you left your wallet somewhere.  Some bar. Christine'll understand.

No. She ordered them special. Took  her forever to find them. They've  got this design on them with dolphins  and our names engraved in Sanskrit.  We've got to go back. Christine'll  fucking crucify me.
No way. No way.
(a pitiful whine) Please, Miles, please.
Forget it. Your wallet was stolen at  a bar. Happens every day.
Jack stares straight ahead, breathing through his mouth a he considers this. Then --
No, we've got to get my wallet! Those  rings are irreplaceable! We've got  to get them, Miles! I fucked up! I  know I fucked up, okay? I fucked up.  You gotta help me. You gotta help  me. Pleeeease!
Jack now descends to a level of wretchedness and desperat that Miles has never seen before in Jack, or in anyone el for that matter.

Oh, God, please... Oh God. I know  I'm bad. I know I did a bad thing.  Help me, Miles. Just this one thing,  this one last thing. I can't lose  Christine. I can't. I'm nothing  without her. Please, Miles, please...  uuuuu... uuuuuu.... uuuuuuu......
No longer able to form words, Jack is reduced to emitting low, primitive sounds. Snot flows from beneath his bandag nose.
Miles drives in the early-morning light. Jack is now subd quieted by his pain and exhaustion.
She tell you she was married?
Yeah.
So what the fuck were you thinking?
Wasn't supposed to be back till six.  Fucker rolls in at five.
Cutting it a little close, don't you  think? (off Jack's silence) So how was she? Compared to Stephanie,  say.
Horny as shit. Flopping around like  a landed trout.
The Saab creeps around a corner.
Jack scans the street.
Yeah, this is the block. Just keep  going... (spotting an AMC Pacer) Yeah! This is it. There's her car.
Miles pulls over and cuts the engine.
So what's the plan?
The plan is... you go.
Me?
My ankle. Just go explain the  situation.
(sarcastic, clearing  his throat) Uh, excuse me, sir, but my friend  was the one balling your wife a couple  hours ago, and he seems to have left  his wallet behind, and we were  wondering...
Yeah, yeah. Like that. Just like  that.
Miles gives Jack a withering look. Jack reaches for the D HANDLE.
Fuck you. I'll get it myself.
(grabbing Jack's shirt) Hold on.
Miles crosses the street and approaches --

Miles presses his ear against the front door. Nothing. Th he notices -- A SLIDING GLASS DOOR a few feet away, just barely cracked open. MILES creeps over, sticks his hand into the open space an pulls back the curtain to reveal -- A LIVING ROOM the is hideously MESSY. Draped over a defor beanbag chair are JACK'S LEVI'S. Miles gathers his courage, carefully slides open the glas door, and creeps inside.

A furtive search of Jack's pockets reveals NOTHING. Then  Miles notices a HIGH-PITCHED SOUND wafting from an open d down a short HALLWAY. Miles feverishly begins foraging through the debris on th floor. Again nothing. Meanwhile the noise from the bedroo grows louder -- female MOANING in odd rhythmic unison wit MAN'S VOICE.
Miles gets on ALL FOURS and starts crawling, weaving his through a trail of shoes and clothes. Nearing the open door, the sounds grow more distinct --
You don't think I fuck you, bitch?  I'll fuck you.
I'm a bad girl. I'm a bad girl.
Miles peers around the corner of the open door to see --
Cammi is TIED to the faux brass headboard. A BIG GUY slam away at her. In the corner a soundless TV shows a PRESIDE PRESS CONFERENCE.
You picked him up and you fucked  him, didn't you, bitch?
I picked him up and I fucked him.  I'm a bad girl.
And you liked fucking him, didn't  you, you fat little whore?
I liked it when you caught me fucking  him.
Whoa! Miles manages to tear his eyes away from this nature  documentary and scan the room.

to the WALLET atop the dresser. Miles's eyes dart back and forth between the couple and t wallet. His HEART BEATING LOUDLY, he goes for it. He scra to his feet, dashes across the room, seizes the wallet an tears out. Behind him he hears --
The fuck was that?
The wallet! He took Derek's wallet!
Miles comes flying out of the sliding glass door, followe swiftly by the man, who is of course STARK NAKED. And he' fast for a man his size.
Get him!
Jack is reclined in the passenger seat FAST ASLEEP. On th radio NPR'S CARL KASSEL reads the news.
Miles comes sprinting towards us, mere steps ahead of Cam naked husband. Finding the car door locked, Miles knocks  loudly on the glass, startling Jack awake.
Open up! Jesus! Open the goddamn  door!
Jack flips the electric locks just in time for Miles to g in before -- WHUMP! The guy's BELLY hits the window. He pounds on the  roof before trying the door, now re-locked.
You motherfuckers! I'll kill you!  I'll kill you motherfuckers!
Miles starts the car and begins to drive away. The guy tr to keep up but can't, running barefoot on asphalt. Jack t to look --
The guy recedes in the distance.
removes the rings from the wallet.
You did it! You fucking did it!
They LAUGH and SLAP HANDS.
For all his failures, this time he did something right.

The shades are drawn. Jack is CRASHED OUT on the bed, sno loudly. Miles folds his shirts and trousers -- readying h bags for departure. At one moment he stops and watches his friend sleep. A KNOCK at the door. Miles goes to answer it, but once hi hand is on the knob, he pauses. If we're perceptive, we w know he's hoping against hope that it's Maya. He opens it. It's just the MAID with her big CART.
Housekeeping.
The Saab enters the freeway and heads south.
Miles drives while Jack stares out the window, WATCHING T LANDSCAPE CHANGE as they leave wine country.
Hey, Jack. Jack.
Hrnrnrn?
That was quite a day yesterday.
Jack's eyes close, but his lips spread into a smile.
Yep. Quite a day.
Quite a week.
A driving shot.
Miles pumps the gas, while nearby Jack stretches his legs As Miles puts the nozzle back in place --
Want me to drive?
No, I'm okay.
Hey, why don't you invite Maya to  the wedding?
Somehow I don't think inviting Maya  to your wedding is the right move.  In fact, after your bullshit, it's  going to be hard for me to even go  to the Hitching Post again.
You're so negative.
Miles replaces the hose and screws on the gas cap.
Come on, let me drive.
I'm fine. You rest.
I feel like driving.
As the car makes its way back toward the freeway, Jack lo over at Miles and slows the car to a stop.
What's wrong?
Nothing. Buckle up, okay?
Miles obeys. Without hesitation, Jack accelerates and JUM THE CURB, heading into --
The Saab plows INTO A TREE.
What the fuck!
(pointing at his face) You said it looked like a car  accident.
What the fuck!
I'll pay for it.
They get out to inspect the damage. The hood is slightly  crumpled, and the front fender is bent.
Look at this!
I don't know. Doesn't look like  anybody got hurt in this one.
Oh, no. Oh, Christ. No, you don't.
You need a new car anyway.
Miles looks at his friend, incredulous.
I said I'd pay for it.
The trunk is open, and the guys are unloading their cases wine. Miles notices that one box is DRIPPING.
You broke some.
Whatever. Sorry.
No, not whatever. You fucking  derelict.
Miles looks on as Jack hoists a FOUNDATION BLOCK toward t open driver's door of the Saab.
You ready?

Miles waves his hand in a gesture of "Get it over with." Grunting with effort, Jack leans inside the car and drops the foundation block onto the GAS PEDAL. Direct hit! Jack leaps backward and hits the dirt just in time. Miles and Jack watch the driverless Saab race toward the  tree, its speed increasing. But just before hitting it, t car drifts to one side and SAILS RIGHT PAST.
Oh, fuck!

The car zooms wildly across the vacant lot and, missing t tree, continues on until CRASHING THROUGH A FENCE and fin toppling headlong into a CEMENT TRENCH. Only the back of car remains visible. The whole thing is finished in a matter of seconds. Still frozen in place, Miles and Jack turn slowly to each other
It's okay. I've got Triple A.
From in front of the Saab, we see its now CRUMPLED HOOD a FENDER, a couple of BUNGEE CORDS holding the whole thing  together.
The Saab approaches the end of the line.
Miles has helped Jack carry his bags and the wine. He plo the last case down.
Well. That about does it.
Why don't you come in?
Uh-uh. You're on your own.
So I'll see you at the rehearsal.
Yeah.
They give each other a brief manly back-slappy hug.
Love you, man.
Back at you.
Miles heads toward the curb.
Hey, don't pull away till they see  the car.
(over his shoulder) Yeah. (turning around) Hey, why wasn't I injured?
(big smile) You were wearing your belt.

Miles gets in and watches through the side window as Mrs. Erganian opens the front door and welcomes Jack with shoc and dismay. Jack points back at -- MILES raising one hand in a feeble wave. The camera slowl MOVES CLOSER as he continues to watch --
weaving his story of woe. He's a great actor when he want to be. Mr. Erganian and a mortified Christine come to the door too. Mr. Erganian takes a few steps toward the car t get a better look.
watching the drama play out. Then his eyes drop as he  momentarily loses himself in melancholy. This reverie is  interrupted by --

head_text.subj: THE VOICE OF AN ARMENIAN PRIEST

text: Startled, Miles turns to look at --
who is singing the BLESSING OF THE RINGS. We are now in --
The church is packed. CLOSE ON THE RINGS as the priest holds them aloft. If those rings could talk... Jack shoots a quick look at  Miles, who looks right back. The priest continues his  blessing.

head_text.subj: AT THE TOP OF THE STAIRS --

text: The WEDDING FAMILIES greet the exiting guests in a RECEIV LINE. Smiling and exuberant, Jack seems utterly at home a the new groom.

head_text.subj: AT THE BOTTOM OF THE STEPS --

text: Miles watches the scene, not without melancholy. Then --
Hey, Miles.

Miles turns and looks up to see Victoria, standing one st above him. Just behind her is her NEW HUSBAND. He exudes quiet confidence of a successful businessman who played  college football, takes expensive skiing and sailing  vacations, and hasn't read a novel since high school.
Hi, Vicki. (taking her in) You look beautiful.
Thanks. Um, this is Ken Cortland, my  husband.
From his spot hovering over Miles, Ken leans down and off his hand.
How are you?
Hi. How you doing? You're a lucky  guy.
Thanks. (to Victoria) I'll wait for you at the car. (to Miles) Nice to meet you, Miles.
Ken.
Exit Ken.
That was big of him.
Yeah, he's good that way. Very  considerate.
That's great.
So how're you doing?
Since the last time we spoke? I don't  know. Could be better. Could be worse.
So what's happening with your book?
Universally rejected. Strike three.
Oh, Miles. That's awful. What are  you going to do?
Back to the drawing board, I guess.  Or not. So... you're married.  Congratulations. You look happy.
I am.
Seems like everyone's getting married.  A year ago it was all divorces. Now  it's all weddings. Cyclical, I guess.
I guess.
Just then a BLACK LINCOLN NAVIGATOR pulls up alongside th curb. The passenger side window is halfway down, and the  sounds of Adult Contemporary Jazz waft out. Victoria give Ken a little wave.
(shifting gears) Well, let's go have some champagne,  shall we? Toast all the newlyweds.
Not me. I'm not drinking.
You quit drinking?
I'm pregnant.
(hit in the solar  plexus) Oh. Huh. Well... (rallying) Congratulations again, Vicki. That's  wonderful news.
(going to the car) See you over there, Miles.
Yeah.
As she gets in the car and cruises away, Miles glances ba at --
-- where Mike Erganian is introducing Jack to some dear o FRIENDS. Mike throws a loving arm around his new son-in-l and Jack is drawn into Mike's bosom.

A HAND-PAINTED SIGN, attached to a STOP SIGH and decorate with balloons, reads: "RECEPTION THIS WAY!" with an arrow pointing RIGHT. One by one, CARS are making a right turn. But when his tu comes, Miles turns LEFT.
The Saab pull up outside. Miles leaves the car idling as sprints inside. Moments later he sprints back to his car, this time carrying SOMETHING.

His bowtie undone, Miles sits at a booth eating. He washe down a bite by draining the contents of a big wax-coated  soft drink cup. He brings the cup to his lap and refills it from a BOTTLE WINE hidden next to him. As he sets the bottle back down, glimpse the label: 1961 Cheval Blanc. He takes another sip. As the camera MOVES CLOSER, all the complex emotions inspired by the wine ripple across Miles face.
"The marrow of his bone," I repeated  aimlessly. This at least penetrated  my mind. Phineas had died from the  marrow of his bone flowing down his  blood stream to his heart.
The voice belongs to one of Miles's PUPILS reading aloud class. Other students follow along silently from their ow copies of A Separate Peace.
Miles sits behind his desk at the front of the class.

I did not cry then or ever about  Finny. I did not cry even when I  stood watching him being lowered  into his family's straight-laced  burial ground outside of Boston. I  could not escape a feeling that this  was my own funeral, and you do not  cry in that case.
The students look up.
Do you want me to keep reading the  next chapter, Mr. Raymond?
(as though coming to) Hrnrnrn? No, we'll pick up there on  Monday.

Miles enters his tiny apartment. He loosens his tie and p down his satchel. On his way to the kitchen, he presses a button on his  ANSWERING MACHINE. As it plays, he opens the REFRIGERATOR and looks inside.
One new message.
Hello, Miles. It's Maya.
Miles FREEZES, not wanting to miss a single syllable.

Thanks for your letter. I would have  called you sooner, but I think I've  needed some time to think about  everything that happened and what  you wrote to me. Another reason I  didn't call sooner is that I wanted  to finish your book, which I finally  did last night.
Miles's heart pounds.

I think it's really lovely, Miles.  You're so good with words. Who cares  if it's not getting published? There  are so many beautiful and painful  things about it. Did you really go  through all that? It must have been  awfully hard. And the sister character -- Jesus, what a wreck. But I have to  say I was really confused by the  ending. Did the father finally commit  suicide, or what? It's driving me  crazy. And the title.
We see ourselves taking the BUELLTON EXIT.

Anyway, it's turned cold and rainy  here lately. But I like winter. So  listen, if you ever do decide to  come up here again, you should let  me know. I would say stop by the  Hitching Post, but to tell you the  truth I'm not sure how much longer  I'm going to be working there. I'm  going to graduate soon so I'll  probably relocate. We'll see.
Miles climbs the wooden steps and approaches Maya's back  door.
Anyway, like I said, I really loved  your novel. Don't give up, Miles.  Keep writing. You're really good.  Hope you're well. Bye.
Miles takes a breath. Finally he KNOCKS. FADE OUT.
